item.title: Pokemon GO: How to Make a PokeStop
item.description:
PokeStops are extremely important in Pokemon GO , and you'll need to spin them to obtain items and complete tasks. Due to the nature of Pokemon GO , PokeStops, appearing as a blue Poke Ball token on the in-game map when nearby, are placed in public areas that are ideal for meeting up or exercising. Unfortunately, this can make spinning PokeStops difficult for rural players.

Once Pokemon GO players reach level 37, they can start nominating new areas for PokeStops. Creating your own PokeStop is a simple albeit lengthy process. To ensure your nomination/submission goes through, you should familiarize yourself with the qualifications of PokeStop creation.

Rules of PokeStops

You can view PokeStop submission rules on the Pokemon GO Help Center. Basically, there are rules you'll want to keep in mind when you're starting your nomination. Following these will increase your chances of your PokeStop submission being added to the game.

  1. Your trainer level needs to be level 37 or higher , and it cannot be a "Child Account ."
  2. The Place of Interest (POI) needs to be accessible to pedestrians .
  3. You cannot nominate private residences or private property. When taking photos for the PokeStop, make sure there are no people, animals, or names/IDs (such as license plates) visible.
  4. Your PokeStop needs to be permanent . Meaning you can't nominate something that's not going to be there year round (ex: a festival stand).
  5. Places such as hospitals or fire stations are ineligible.

How to Submit a PokeStop

Here's how you can nominate a PokeStop in Pokemon GO :

  1. Select the Poke Ball/main menu icon.
  2. Choose "Settings", then select "Upload."
  3. Choose "New Pokestop" to begin the process. You have 40 PokeStop nominations per day.

If this is your first time contributing a PokeStop, you'll be prompted to complete the "Wayfarer tutorial." Click the link when prompted, and log in using the same account as your GO account. This means you can login using your google/gmail account, facebook, apple, etc. Once you've made an account on Wayfarer, exit out of Pokemon GO then return to the PokeStop menu in Settings/Uploads . If it works, you'll see a series of directions upon clicking the "New PokeStop" button.

After selecting "New PokeStop," you'll have to do the following (in order):

  1. Set Location . You'll need to pin the orange/red marker on the POI you are trying to nominate. You can switch between Satellite or Map mode. Be sure that the marker is placed where you can reach it.
  2. Take a PokeStop Photo . This is the photo that will be used on the Photo Disc. You'll want the location/POI's photo to be in focus, free of visual obstructions (people and animals), and clear. Try to avoid taking the photo at night; make sure the camera isn't angled.
  3. Show the Surrounding Area . You'll be prompted to take another photo, but this time from a different angle of the PokeStop. This is to ensure that the PokeStop is in a safe and non-disruptive location.
  4. Describe the Location . You need to create a title as well as a detailed description for the PokeStop. If the location has an official name, use it. You'll also want to be sure your description includes any cultural significance/value of the location. Try not to make the description too lengthy.
  5. Categorize this location . You'll have a list to choose from to categorize the PokeStop, such as Garden, Residential Building, Stadium, etc. If you can't find exactly what you're looking for, type a keyword related to the PokeStop into the above search bar, and it should give you some suggestions.
  6. Show Why Your Nomination is Important . This is similar to the "Describe the Location," but not quite the same, either. You'll need to explain why your nomination is important to the community and why this would make it an ideal PokeStop.

Do not be informal in your description or title. Doing so will likely prevent your submission from going through. Follow the rules before sending in a submission.

Once you've submitted a PokeStop, you'll be notified via email that it was received. Your submission will then be evaluated by the Wayfarer Community before it's deemed eligible or ineligible. In the case it's declined, you'll have a chance to appeal the decision.

This process can take days to months for a PokeStop to be accepted or declined. However, you can potentially speed up the process by "Upgrades." This is a feature on Wayfarer that becomes available to you if you've contributed reviews on other people's submissions (on the Wayfarer website).

Why a PokeStop Could Be Rejected

To better understand how PokeStops work, you should know that Wayfarer is a community-based platform owned by Niantic that connects all their apps (ex: Pokemon GO , Ingress ). Any submissions for PokeStops that you send in-game will be judged by Wayfarer's community rather than Niantic itself. You can also join the community to review submissions. If you want to see your PokeStop submissions added to the game as soon as possible, it's recommended you do this.

In some cases, a Wayspot may be used in another one of Niantic's games, thus interfering with the placement of a PokeStop. There can only be one PokeStop within a Level 17 S2 Cell. S2 Cells are part of a grid system that determines the eligibility of a point of interest's location. This isn't something you should stress over, but if you're submitting PokeStops and keep getting rejected, it's possible there's already a PokeStop in that cell.

item.title: Mass Effect 4 Should Learn a Valuable Lesson from Mass Effect 1's Tali Romance
item.description:
The Mass Effect series might be on ice for now, but that hasn't done much to stop the hype train from barreling full force toward Mass Effect 4 , the next game in the series. Mass Effect 4 will be the franchise's return to the spotlight after the controversial launch and subsequent lukewarm reception of Mass Effect Andromeda , so BioWare is no doubt feeling the pressure to perform.

Luckily, the long-running RPG studio has access to a wealth of invaluable lessons in the form of the original Mass Effect trilogy—three games that are regularly cited as some of the best ever made. Certainly, one can only hope that BioWare will adopt the best parts of those early games—parts that were inexplicably left behind for Andromeda —but Mass Effect 4 could also serve as an opportunity for BioWare to get certain things right, that the first three games got wrong. ME4 will effectively be a second "first" game for the franchise (or third, if one counts Andromeda as more of a reboot than a spin-off). In other words, BioWare will be using ME4 to reintroduce audiences to the Mass Effect universe after more than a decade, so it should be even better than the games that preceded it, ideally.

Mass Effect 4 Should Avoid Repeating Mass Effect 1's Romance Problems

Fan-Favorite Characters Like Tali Weren't Romanceable Until Mass Effect 2

Most of Mass Effect 's iconic characters are introduced in the first game, and that includes romance options: amorous crew members like Liara T'Soni and Ashley Williams make their debut in Mass Effect 1 . They're joined by other famously romanceable NPCs like Tali'Zorah and Garrus Vakarian, though neither of them are eligible for romance until the second game. There are a number of explanations for why BioWare may have omitted these characters' romance subplots, but the most probable is rather simple: the Quarians and Turians were likely not viewed as having enough relatability or sex appeal, unlike a human character like Kaiden Alenko or the decidedly human-like Asari NPCs.

Fans have also pointed to Tali's age in Mass Effect 1 as a possible reason why she was initially non-romanceable, but this theory is flawed: Tali is 22 in Earth years in ME1 , making her just three years younger than Ashley, whose age is of no consequence. Also, this theory does nothing to explain why Garrus was off the table at first.

Whatever the reason, BioWare chose not to make these characters available as romance options from the outset, only putting them in those roles come Mass Effect 2 , after the series gained millions of fans, many of whom expressed their interest in these teammates. And it's a good thing that BioWare made this call, since the Tali and Garrus romance plots are typically referenced as some of the best in the series. That's not exactly surprising, since Tali and Garrus are two of the best-written characters in Mass Effect , but it's telling that BioWare needed to be prompted by fans before committing to this narrative path. Hopefully, the same mistake won't be repeated in ME4 .

Mass Effect 4 Shouldn't Be Contingent Upon Fan Feedback

Leaving Tali's and Garrus' romance stories for ME2 and ME3 is representative of a bigger problem: the lack of a cohesive, determined creative vision at the franchise's outset. Thankfully, creativity and vision are two resources that the original Mass Effect trilogy otherwise has in droves, so these delayed romances don't cause too great an issue. One could even argue that the Tali and Garrus romances are better in the long run, since Shepard got to be just friends with them first. But this is a happy coincidence, and shouldn't be taken as a gold standard or template to follow. If there are characters in Mass Effect 4 that are worthy of a romance subplot, then BioWare should give it to them, regardless of what the studio predicts fans might think.

item.title: Final Fantasy 14 Director Reveals Which Recent Game Impressed Him The Most
item.description:
The director of Final Fantasy 14 , Naoki Yoshida, has shared particularly high praise for The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom . The director spoke on the subject following his recent appearance at Anime Expo, where he was a Guest of Honor for his work on Final Fantasy 14 , among other releases over the years.

The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom received praise overall from the community and game reviewers at large, but it's likely not the game most fans think of when asked what their favorite Zelda game is on the Switch. The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom stands alongside both Breath of the Wild and Tears of the Kingdom , which were both smash-hits upon arrival. Breath of the Wild changed the series' formula with new physics, a massive open world, and a bunch of brand-new characters, but that innovation also meant development on the game took considerable time and cost.

In an interview with Japanese publication Famitsu, Naoki Yoshida, aka Yoshi-P, talked briefly about games that he was particularly impressed by. Yoshi-P noted that he thought that all recently released games were interesting, but pointed to The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom as the one that stood out for him. He said that what was notable to him in particular was the way that the game was made, sharing especially high praise for how it reused existing assets, allowing the developers to focus "all of their efforts on the fun." He noted that he believed this came about due to the combination of veterans and young developers who worked on the game.

Final Fantasy 14's Yoshi-P Recommends Echoes of Wisdom to Future Game Devs

Yoshi-P also shared that he was impressed that the game kept production costs to a minimum through this method of reusing game assets, "with the understanding that sales may not grow as explosively as the main game(s)." He went on to call Echoes of Wisdom "extremely noteworthy" and suggested that those who are studying to become game developers and newcomers in the industry should consider playing the game from the same perspective.

Echoes of Wisdom may not have captivated the average Nintendo fan as much as the mainline entries of late. However, it nonetheless provides a fun gameplay experience and finally answered the long-standing plea for Zelda to be the main character in one of the series' games. From both a development standpoint and a normal gamer's point of view, the title was a success, with The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom moving over 2.58 million units by late September 2024.

item.title: 8 Best Games That Take Place In Desolate Environments
item.description: When it comes to desolate settings, some games lean a little too hard on dull colors and empty landscapes. But the best ones go further, blending eerie visuals with gameplay mechanics that make every step through the ruins feel meaningful.

item.title: Helldivers 2's Constant Quest for Higher Difficulty is a Double-Edged Sword
item.description:
Helldivers 2 has a complicated history with its own difficulty. One of the moust famous (or infamous) moments in the game's history was a major controversy over nerfs to the players' arsenals in an attempt by Arrowhead Game Studios to introduce more difficulty. Since then, the studio has more often leaned on adjustments to NPC units and weapons, rather than taking power out of Helldivers 2 players' hands, which is way better for the game's explosive power fantasy. Still, that fantasy relies on sufficiently daunting enemies who make the player's power feel well-spent, so it's good to hear that Helldivers 2 's developers are still looking for ways to make the game harder.

It should be said that Helldivers 2 is already a versatile game in the difficulty department; it launched with nine tiers of difficulty, offering appropriate challenge levels for both the most casual and most masochistic players. Since then, it has added a tenth difficulty tier and a litany of daunting new enemies in each faction, but Arrowhead remains committed to making the game more difficult. On the one hand, this is great, since it makes every hour spent playing Helldivers 2 feel more worthwhile, but on the other hand, Arrowhead should be careful to ensure this objective remains in balance with other ways to improve the game.

Difficulty is One Piece of the Helldivers Puzzle

Increasing Helldivers 2 's difficulty (whether by updates and additions to the enemy roster, or new tiers of mission difficulty) simply makes sense for a few reasons:

  • Higher difficulty rewards player mastery in a major way. Every hour spent perfecting aim, memorizing enemy weaknesses, and fine-tuning loadouts directly gets put to the test when Helldivers 2 turns up the challenge level.
  • More menacing enemies and difficulty levels reflect the escalation of the Second Galactic War perfectly. It's only natural that the Terminids, Automatons, and Illuminate would up their game as the battle rages on.
  • In particular, new difficulty levels come with higher output of XP, Requisition Slips, and Samples, materially rewarding players for being willing to risk it all.

However, difficulty is only one dial Arrowhead can turn to fine-tune Helldivers 2 . It shouldn't come to rely on difficulty as the primary way to engage players. The problem with doing this is that making a game more and more difficult ultimately has diminishing returns, because there comes a point when enemy forces are so overwhelmingly oppressive that the game simply feels unfair, and therefore unfun. Higher difficulty levels are only as interesting as the ways that the player can deal with them, so it would be best if Helldivers 2 pursues them in moderation, not as a primary goal.

Helldivers 2 Has a Lot of Ways to Improve Itself

Ideally, any future addition to Helldivers 2 that makes it harder will be paired with other system changes that diversify the experience. For example, applying new enemies or higher difficulty tiers becomes exponentially more interesting when paired with new Helldivers 2 mission types, stratagems, or guns. Perhaps Arrowhead could even add entirely new categories of primary weapons, for example, or use its growing roster of human NPC allies to create elaborate new escort missions. Helldivers 2 still has lots of room to grow. Best of all, a new faction in Helldivers 2 could one day provide a whole new sense of challenge on its own.

Difficulty is inherent to Helldivers 2 's identity; every trailer from the time of the game's reveal highlighted the overwhelming odds faced by Super Earth's Helldivers, and the scorched-earth tactics players will need to survive. That means it's great to hear that Arrowhead is still exploring options to make the game harder, so long after launch. At the same time, difficulty can't be treated as the primary way to expand the game; Arrowhead wants its players to succeed, after all. Any future increases to difficulty should be used to entice players to engage with all the other new things the game has to offer.
